title: Live, Laugh, Leuven
content:
The 14:47 from London prattled through the European countryside like a wine drunk Australian backpacker who got separated from their Contiki tour. On board were 675 passengers, 28 pets, 2,346 of those little cans of Pringles that only hold like 15 Pringii and cost 7 euros, and two 10-year olds huddled in the toilets to avoid the 6 ticket inspectors.[1]


It was only once the train had eased out of Paris and was well on its way to Brussels that they emerged furtively, like teenage meerkats from their bedroom burrows (yes, I watched Meerkat Manor, sue me) before scampering away to some empty seats. Ewen had texted his Uncle Joe to tell him they had “missed” their stop, while Maya gleefully perused her new copy of Cosmo picked up from a station kiosk. Now that their ambitious escape had been made, they pored over maps of Leuven printed from the Bridgend library.


“Let’s run it again,” Ewen began. “We’ll arrive in Brussels in?”


“90 minutes,” Maya answered, soldier-like.


“From there, the train to Leuven will take us?”


“Twenty-four minutes.”


“The next train from Paris to Brussels is in?”


“Forty-seven minutes.”


“So we have how many minutes until Uncle Joe finds us?”


There was a pause. “We never thought that far into the plan,” Maya replied sheepishly.


“You’re right. Let’s call it an hour.”


“Sixty minutes, got it. That should give us time to find the safe house, get inside, get as many clues as we can, come back out, get some waffles, get some triple cooked fries, see if a stranger will let us try Belgian beer, eat some chocolate, learn some Flemmish swear words, eat some of those spiral shaped chips on a stick….Am I forgetting anything?”

“Maybe solve the mystery of the Oracle and stop the world from ending?”


“Right. Sir, yes sir!” Maya barked, causing the other passengers to jump and shake their heads.


Ewen looked around apologetically, then leaned in and whispered, “And maybe we should practice trying to lay low as well.”

“Good thinking”, Maya whispered back, before returning to her Cosmo.[2] “You can be a little overdramatic at times.”


****

Heeding the advice of our couples therapist, my wife and I decided to take a short holiday. We were on our flight awaiting take-off when a lady boarded with her dog. It was one of those adorable, wise-looking pups, the kind that if it barked at you, you would instinctively know it was telling you a little boy had fallen down the well (not again!). The thing was utterly charming, trotting up and down the aisles, sniffing our feet like a furry diplomat of wholesome goodness. Everyone was smitten, passengers and crew alike.

As the flight went on, the novelty started wearing thin. The dog kept escaping its carrier,  shedding tumbleweeds of fur onto people’s clothes and pouncing on strangers trying to nap. Passengers began to glare at the owner, who would flash an apologetic smile and wrestle the thing into submission. Then everyone would melt again because, honestly, how can you stay mad at something that cute? It’s not his fault he’s such a curious, energetic boy, is it? No it isn’t, no it isn’t, you curious energetic boy, yes you are!

Eventually, as we were descending for landing, the dog escaped one final time and bolted down the center aisle. He stopped dead next to my seat. I don’t know if it was the sudden drop in altitude or the airplane snacks, but the poor creature started to whimper and shake, and then: explosive diarrhoea, a veritable fountain, right there on the carpet. The smell was apocalyptic. It singed our nostrils. To this day, my wife can’t smell peanut butter. The young man across from me screamed like he’d been scalded by acid and leapt up onto his seat, presumably to save his pristine-white sneakers. A flight attendant sprinted down the aisle to tell him to stay seated and ran right through the murky puddle, like a bus down a flooded street, spraying filthy wash all over the passengers on either side.

Now all hell broke loose. 

People were shrieking and gagging, covering their mouths and eyes with whatever fabric was at hand. Some wept while others prayed to whichever God would listen, as the bowels of this canine were the bowels of Hell itself. Sometimes at night, I can still hear the screaming. The owner frantically chased her dog toward the cockpit while it continued dousing the entire aisle with liquid shame. This dog had taken command of the craft more expertly than a Somali pirate. The airtight tube of the cabin was now a hotbox of the most rancid kind, with none of us able to leave. What had started as a universally beloved experience had transformed into a garish nightmare, an assault on our senses and our very dignity that we were forced to endure from our shackled seats.

If you’ve never visited Belgium, it’s basically the same thing.

*****

The spiral staircase inside the dilapidated building seemed to go upward forever. Even for two energetic children, the climb toward the seventh floor was taxing. They had found their way to the safehouse simply enough; a train to Leuven, a short walk to the Library with the carillon, and then a bit of hunting to find the blood-red-brick apartment building with the orange door that Ewen had seen in his resurfacing. As they stood outside debating the best way to get inside (Maya had suggested climbing the drainpipe but the very thought of it made Ewen shudder), a kindly old woman let them into the building as she was on her way out.

Now they stood outside the last door on the seventh floor corridor, with its low slanting ceiling and grimy walls. The same door Evelyn and Camille had stood outside many times before. Ewen tried turning the handle, first one way then the other, but with no success. There would be no kindly old lady to help them this time.

“Let me see if there’s another way around”, he said as he started back down the corridor. He hadn’t gotten far when he heard a primal roar, a thud, and then a delighted squeal. He turned back to see the door swinging on its hinges and Maya’s grinning face.

“Cosmo recommends that when kicking down a door: use your heel, kick near the lock and drive the heel of your standing foot into the ground.”

“Why would Cosmo teach you how to-”

“To make sure your boyfriend isn’t cheating on you when he’s locked in his room.”

As he stepped inside the room Ewen’s entire world seemed to lurch forwards. While Maya only saw the ransacked cabinets, strewn papers and toppled corkboard, Ewen was launched into a chaotic flurry of memories; Evelyn and Camille dissecting leads and clues, the ambush by masked attackers, countless late nights and narrow escapes.  The sound of a thousand voices at a million moments blared in his brain like an oncoming train. And he was stuck on the tracks, unable to move or think, until the sound grew louder and the collision, his end, was inevitab-

“Ewen!” Maya’s voice, it was always her voice, scooping him back from the brink. “You were right, everything is still here!”

She was holding a photograph, crumpled and worn, of two women sitting in the corner of this very apartment. They were both in their late twenties, with smiling faces and tired eyes. Empty liquor bottles lay littered around them. It was blurred and poorly framed, clearly taken unsighted by the subjects themselves. Maya pointed to the blond woman on the left. “Is this her?”

Ewen nodded. That was Camille, there was no mistaking her, the piercing green eyes and angular face. She looked exactly like he had seen in his resurfacing.

“So then, this is…uh, was…you?”

Ewen’s eyes shifted to the woman beside Camille, olive skinned with tight dark curls. Something stirred deep within him, though he couldn’t place the feeling. He couldn’t comprehend that his very soul had awakened and was pounding against concrete slabs enclosing his mind, screaming recognition, pummeling with bloodied knuckles, straining to join the tenuous thread of memories that linked this life with those past to unlock powers untold within the boy. Instead, he wondered if this is what dogs feel like when they look in the mirror.

For the next thirty-four minutes, the children rummaged through the remnants of the old safehouse. Maya found a collection of false passports, each bearing Evelyn's face but an assortment of different names, from Helena Dubois to Nacima Gatto. Ewen discovered a drawer full of coded messages and what appeared to be blueprints of an underground facility tunneled into a cliff face. The toppled corkboard was brimming with photographs: officials in suits, scientists in lab coats, aerial shots of dense rainforest and icy mountains. All circling a small, hand-scribbled  note in the centre of the board: Oracle, 2025.

They were both so absorbed in their hunt that they barely spoke, barely looked up from the  strewn floor, barely noticed the soft creak of footsteps on the ancient wooden stairs outside, or the door handle turning slowly.

Maya looked up first, her eyes widening as she saw the tall, bulky figure silhouetted in the doorway. He was middle-aged, with dark flowing hair and a prominent nose, wearing a trenchcoat that had seen better days. A set of keys dangled from his hand as his eyes swept the room, taking in the scattered papers, before settling on the two frozen children. They widened with an expression of startled recognition.

For an instant, nobody moved. The stranger's mouth opened as if to speak, but the children were already bolting for the door.

The man stepped forward, raising his hands in what might have been a peaceful gesture, but the pair didn’t wait to find out. Maya shoulder-checked the stranger (Cosmo page 43, “How To Impress A Guy With Your Football Skills”) as they fled past him into the corridor, sending him stumbling backward into the doorframe.

Wait!” The man called after them. “Please, I need to-"

They were barrelling down the spiral staircase now, taking the steps three at a time. Ewen’s teeth rattled as he leaped from landing to landing. Behind them, they could hear the man's heavy footsteps thundering in pursuit, along with the occasional grunt and curse.

"Why is everyone always chasing us?" Ewen panted as they reached the fourth floor.

"Maybe you should ask your past life!" Maya shot back, vaulting over the banister to skip an entire flight. Maybe she should start participating in PE?

They burst out the building's front door and down the cobblestone street, immediately drawing stares from passerbys. The stranger emerged seconds later, his coat billowing as he scanned left and right.

The children sprinted toward the town centre, weaving in and out of the crowded footpaths, squeezing between tables and diners enjoying the sunshine on the outdoor terraces. Ewen’s legs were burning. His vision blurred, colors bleeding together like the tear-stained words in my diary after my first break up.[3]  Over the sound of blood thundering in his ears, his footsteps on the stony street and his ragged breath, a faint, familiar music drifted into his awareness. The carillion bells were sounding at the Library. He felt a memory start to rise within him; hot pursuit, Evelyn’s escape, ringing bells and slippery cobbles. She has to keep running. But where can she go?

The rendezvous point near the river. Of course.

"This way!" Ewen yanked Maya into a narrow alley between two medieval buildings.”I know a spot!”

 The ancient stones were slick with moisture and their stumbling footsteps echoed off the walls. The alley began to slope downward, where Ewen took a sharp right into an even narrower alley, barely wide enough to stretch out their arms. They scampered along as the cold walls on either side grew closer and closer, until a final left turn brought them back into a larger impasse. Just metres ahead of them was a pedestrian street, and beyond that the Dijle river. People streamed past them along the street, completely oblivious to this small gap between the buildings where the children now struggled to catch their breath.

“How did you know about this place?” Maya puffed.

“Evelyn,” Ewen managed. “Guess this wasn’t my first time being chased in Leuven. Wait, are you eating fries?”

Maya stopped munching and looked down at the handful of fries in her palm. “You know I don’t do fight or flight. I’m more snack or attack.”

“Where did you even get those!”

“I swiped them when we ran past that bistro.” There was a crunch. “Wow, shyou can really tashte the triple-cooking,” Maya said through a mouthful.

Ewen was about to ask for a taste when a shadow fell upon the pair. The stranger had found them. He stood towering over the children. 

“He’s got the nose of a bloodhound!” Maya yelled. She thrust her hand into her jacket pocket and made a finger-gun, pointing it at him. “I’m armed! Don’t come any closer or I’ll shoot!”

"Please," the man said, extending his hands again. Up close, his face looked more desperate than menacing. "I can help you understand. I knew Evely-."

A blur of motion came from their left. Uncle Joseph materialised from thin air, like a bullet from a gun, crunching the stranger in a tackle that folded him like a lawnchair. Onlookers screamed and scattered as both men splayed out across the cobblestones. Joseph rolled to his feet with surprising agility for a man who had just spent all his energy on the takedown of the stranger, who lay groaning on the ground.

“Hello, Ewen,” he panted between wheezing breaths. “I'm your Uncle Joseph. Bienvenue à Paris. Look how- whew, give me a sec. Look how you’ve grown. Did you have a good journey? Are you hungry? Do you need the loo? Was that too many questions?”

The children stared at him incredulously. “No, just the right amount,” Ewen squeaked.

“Oh, thank God.” Joe slumped to the ground and held his knees while he caught his breath. Maya walked over to him and placed a tentative hand on his shoulder.

“That was amazing,” she murmured, awestruck.

Joe chuckled and turned to look at her. “And you must be Maya.” 

“Maya Singh,” she replied, before looking down at the battered stranger, still laying crumpled on the cobblestones. She saw an opportunity and put on her best Caruso voice.

“And now it’s time to make him sing.”[4]

footnotes.content: For all my number-lovers out there, this sentence was for you. Only the real ones will take the next step.
